ratings.question_text: How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: This class should have a field trip every single week; with lectures to complement. There should be routine tests to help students commit a substantial amount of information to memory. Natural history could be better incorporated into the class, which, as it stands, puts much more emphasis on pure identification and classification.
With a little redesign this course could be really great. I didn't get quite the level of abstract taxonomic knowledge I would have liked. But I can also see how others may not be interested in that.
9c: the fieldtrips were where all learning was done. by far the most valuable aspect of class.

I strongly recommend this course to all FES'ers. It should probably be a foundation course, given the importance the material has for all at FES or those interested in anything environmental. How can we graduate students without them knowing the types of trees in the area they're graduating from and spent ~two years in?
The field trips were very useful, especially for the practical.
Field trips to cool forests in and around New Haven.
the field trips. they should happen rain or shine, every week, past leaf-off.
Field trips were really great.
Field trips
being out in the woods.

The field trips, and mostly the actual outcome of learning to identify trees. It was also good and a great relief to have a sample final not too dissimilar from the final itself, since the questions involve many small things throughout the course that one may not have thought to look over.

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: The lectures.
I felt that the course was haphazardly organized, which made it difficult to learn the material. More structure is needed.
lectures. these do not help students to organize their thinking about phylogeny and tree families; they are simply photo albums of different trees (we could look at them in the field!)
Periodic testing throughout the course instead of two big tests. Better connection between morphological characteristics of higher taxonomic classes and genera.

I think planning ahead to know exactly what species you plan to find so that you have some branches accessible. Many species we saw too often and some key ones we either never saw or only saw once and they were hard to learn. I think perhaps this should be a one credit class just about the botany, not about the cladistics.
the instruction. too much pointing and saying: this is Xxxx xxxxxxx. not very creative or well-planned.
Lectures (perhaps make it more interactive with the students during the class?)

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: TA and instructor both made themselves available and accessible.
He always offered to make himself available.
Very available. Lectures were a little much after a great series of field trips.
Generally, whenever i contacted either instructor or TA i received a swift response and good help when needed. Thanks!

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: Dendrology is essential to my future career
As said in Question 11.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: To be able to identify trees and plants in New England.

interested in how different species are related to one another and why we see them where we do. wanted a field-based course that would help me grow more familiar with place and understand the evolution of trees and forest systems.
See above
To learn my trees.
To learn to identify trees.

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: Yes.
While I did learn a little, I don't feel it was a good use of my time. This material could be taught in a different format, like a TSM or one credit class.
no.

Partly. I learned a lot of tree ID in New England. I had hoped for a better understanding of the morphological characteristics that define families and orders from one another. That may be a different class though - botany.
despite all i've said, yes. i loved being in the woods.
Yes. Thanks : )

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: Yes.
I thought I would come away with more information than I did.
Pretty much. Overall a good course.
Thankfully so.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Practice on your own outside of class in addition to the field trips.
I don't recommend this class.
pursue routine field trips on your own outside of class. give yourself a quiz every week on a different family.
Study along the whole time and not just before the final (duh)
Start studying early.
keep learning and remembering from the start. don't leave it all to cramming.
Make the most out of the field trips.
